thread.title: Labor claims Malcolm Turnbull's $1.75m donation 'bought' the election | Australia news
thread.title_full: Labor claims Malcolm Turnbull's $1.75m donation 'bought' the election | Australia news | The Guardian

author: Paul Karp
title: Labor claims Malcolm Turnbull's $1.75m donation 'bought' the election | Australia news
text:
Labor has accused Malcolm Turnbull of “buying” the 2016 election after he revealed he donated $1.75m to the Liberal party.
But the energy and environment minister, Josh Frydenberg , has defended the prime minister, describing his as the “purest donation of all” because there could be no suggestion the money bought influence from the government.
On Wednesday evening Turnbull confirmed he had given $1.75m to the Liberal party , explaining that he had made the “significant contribution” to ensure that Labor was not elected at the July double dissolution.
“I’ve always been a supporter of the causes I believe in – Lucy and I have always been generous … because we know we’ve done well in life and believe it’s part of our duty to give back,” he said.
Labor finance spokesman, Jim Chalmers, said it was “no wonder” Turnbull had wanted to keep the figure secret because it showed he had “basically bought himself an election”.

Malcolm Turnbull reveals he donated $1.75m to Liberal party Read more 
“He couldn’t rely on the power of his arguments or his policies to win the election – he had to buy it.”
Chalmers claimed Turnbull wouldn’t be Liberal leader or prime minister “if he didn’t have $1.75m in his back pocket”.
On ABC News Breakfast, Frydenberg defended Turnbull, dismissing the suggestion he wouldn’t be prime minister without the donation and he must be angry the party didn’t show more gratitude.
“No, look, the point is the prime minister has made this donation public. 
“He’s abided by all of the rules and the hypocrisy of the Labor party who receive millions of dollars from the union movement, which in fact does determine their policy positions, is – they are the ones that have the case to answer.”

Frydenberg tried to turn the donation into a positive, arguing: “There is no inference of influence when a person makes a donation to their own campaign. In fact, it is the purest donation of all.”
He also noted that opposition leader, Bill Shorten, had received a $40,000 donation from a construction labour hire company, which he only declared when it was discovered by the trade union royal commission.
The treasurer, Scott Morrison, hit back at Chalmers in an interview with Radio National, labelling the claim Turnbull had “bought” the election a “grubby political smear” from a “political hack”. He challenged Shorten to repeat the claim.
Morrison also noted unions had donated $20m to the Labor party, which he said amounted to Shorten “putting his hand into the pocket of every union member in the country” to fund Labor’s campaign.
Speaking on Radio National after Morrison, Chalmers said it would come as “no surprise” to voters that unions, the industrial wing of the labour movement, donated to the Labor party, the political wing.
“The point we’re making is that the prime ministership ... should be determined by the person who has the better policies for this country, not the person who has the most zeroes on their bank balance,” he said.
Chalmers accepted that politicians are allowed to make personal political donations, and that state and federal Labor MPs pay a levy of 4-6% of their salaries to their Labor branches.
But he said Turnbull’s was the biggest personal political donation in history.
Chalmers said the Australian people would ultimately judge whether it was good for democracy “that one of the leaders can find $1.75m down the back of the couch to spray around in the dying days of the election”.
He said Turnbull must himself think the donation was “pretty dodgy or it wouldn’t have taken seven months for the figure to be dragged out of him”.
On Wednesday Turnbull addressed donation reform in his first major speech for 2017 at the National Press Club, suggesting that the current disclosure rules were a result of historical administration requirements.
He said he would have no objection to more timely donation reforms and said it was a matter for the joint standing committee on electoral matters, which is examining political donations .
Turnbull agreed in principle that public information should be disclosed “more promptly or in as close to real time as possible”.
